payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm

Thanks!

content.text:
<user_instructions>

# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm

Thanks!



</user_instructions>

# Context from my IDE setup:

## My request for Codex:
We need to implement process support in our kernel. Start with the following:

What you must save/restore

Per thread (always):

General registers needed to continue execution: at minimum the callee-saved ones (RBX, RBP, R12–R15) for a kernel-only switch frame; but you also keep a full trap frame when you entered the kernel from user mode (see below).

RSP (stack pointer) for the thread’s current stack.

RIP (next instruction) and RFLAGS — these live in the trap frame for user→kernel entries; for pure kernel→kernel context switches you store a return address on the switch stack.

FPU/SIMD state (XMM/YMM/ZMM) via FXSAVE/FXRSTOR or XSAVE/XRSTOR. Start eager (always save/restore); add lazy later.

FS/GS base if you use them for TLS/per-CPU (via MSR_{FS,GS}_BASE). Also handle SWAPGS correctly on syscall/interrupt paths.

Per process (on process switch):

CR3 (address space / PML4) — switching processes means switching CR3.

TSS.RSP0 (kernel stack used on next user→kernel transition).

Optional: PKRU (if using memory protection keys), debug regs (if you support hardware watchpoints).

You do not copy the stack’s memory; you just save the pointer(s). The stack contents live in the process’s pages and will still be there when you switch back.

How it fits together

Entering the kernel (interrupt/exception vs syscall)
Interrupt/exception gates (int, faults, IRQs): hardware pushes RIP, CS, RFLAGS, RSP, SS (if from user) onto the current stack, giving you a natural trap frame. Save the rest of GPRs you care about and you have a complete snapshot to resume user code with iretq.

syscall/sysret: hardware moves user RIP into RCX and RFLAGS into R11; it does not save RSP for you. Your entry stub must save RCX/R11 and capture user RSP into your trap frame.

A common C layout for the trap frame (what you restore to return to user mode):

Then migrate our 'built in' commands to processes.
